title: 107_hr2830
content: The "Voting Restoration Act" is the short title of this Act, which aims to restore voting rights. The Voting Restoration Act aims to restore voting rights by addressing disparities in voting eligibility standards for ex-felons across different states. Congress asserts its supervisory power over federal elections to ensure voting rights are not denied based on race, sex, color, or previous servitude. In 13 States, ex-offenders face disenfranchisement even after completing their sentences. The process to regain voting rights is challenging, requiring a pardon or order from the Governor in 8 States, action from the parole or pardon board in 2 States, and a Presidential pardon for Federal offenders in 16 States. Approximately 3,900,000 Americans, or 2 percent of the adult population, are ineligible to vote due to felony convictions. Three-fourths of these individuals are on probation, parole, or are ex-offenders. In recent years, the number of incarcerated individuals has grown exponentially, with drug policies contributing to this increase. One in four prison inmates in 1998 was incarcerated for a drug offense, and drug offenders made up 58 percent of Federal prison inmates. Over one-third of women in prison are also incarcerated for drug offenses, which are predominantly nonviolent. Racially disparate sentencing laws have led to African-Americans being overrepresented in Federal drug charges. Minorities, particularly African-Americans, are disproportionately impacted by laws that strip felons of their voting rights. Currently, 13 percent of African-American men are unable to participate in Federal elections due to felony convictions. Congress should address these disparities to ensure all Americans have the right to vote in Federal elections. The purpose of this Act is to restore voting eligibility to individuals who have completed criminal sentences. The purpose of this Act is to restore voting eligibility to individuals who have completed sentences for criminal offenses and promote their participation in civic life. SEC. 3. PROTECTION OF RIGHT TO VOTE AND REGISTER TO VOTE IN FEDERAL ELECTIONS. The right to vote in Federal elections cannot be denied based on a felony conviction, except while under state custody. Individuals can take legal action if this right is violated. If a violation of voting rights is not corrected within a specified timeframe, the aggrieved person can bring a civil action for relief in court without the need to provide prior notice to the election official. The Attorney General can bring a civil action in court for declaratory or injunctive relief to remedy a violation of the Act. If a violation occurs within 3 days of a federal election, compensatory damages can be requested in the civil action without prior notice to the election official. Grant program to assist states in protecting rights of ex-felons to vote and register in federal elections. Establishment of a program where the Attorney General awards grants to eligible States to help individuals convicted of felonies vote in Federal elections by providing information and increasing voter registration rates. The program awards grants to eligible States to increase voter registration rates among individuals with felony convictions. States must meet eligibility requirements and submit an application to the Attorney General. The grant amount is determined based on the total appropriation for the fiscal year. The program awards grants to eligible States to increase voter registration rates among individuals with felony convictions. The grant amount is determined based on the total appropriation for the fiscal year and the number of convicted felons in the State and all eligible States. The program under this Act provides information to felons about their voting rights and eligibility to register to vote. States receiving grants must establish a program to inform individuals convicted of felonies about their voting status. The State must inform individuals under custody or supervision about their right to register to vote and the impact of plea bargains on their voting rights. The State must inform individuals convicted of a felony about their right to register to vote and vote, including the impact of plea bargains on their voting rights. Activities should be carried out to notify individuals of their voting rights upon release from custody or completion of supervision. Each State receiving a grant under this Act must report to the Attorney General within 30 days after the year ends, detailing program activities and informing convicted felons of their right to vote. The program aims to reduce the number of felonies that result in loss of voting rights. The program under this Act aims to increase voter registration rates among individuals convicted of felonies by reducing the number of felonies that lead to disenfranchisement. States receiving grants must establish effective methods to achieve this goal. The program aims to increase voter registration rates among felons by establishing an index of eligible individuals and increasing registration rates by at least 50% over a 5-year period. The program aims to increase voter registration rates among felons by establishing an index of eligible individuals and increasing registration rates by at least 50% over a 5-year period. States receiving grants must carry out activities to increase voting rates among convicted felons and seek cooperative agreements with service providers for assistance. Each State receiving a grant under the program must report to the Attorney General within 30 days after the year ends, detailing activities and the number of convicted felons registered to vote and who voted in the recent elections. The Attorney General will provide technical assistance to help States implement the funded programs. The Attorney General must submit an annual report to Congress on the activities of the grant-funded program. Appropriations are authorized for the first 5 fiscal years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. RESPONSIBILITIES OF DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE REGARDING INDIVIDUALS CONVICTED OF FEDERAL FELONIES. The Attorney General will maintain an index of individuals convicted of federal felonies under federal custody or supervision. They must inform individuals of their right to vote during plea bargaining and upon conviction, release, or completion of federal custody. The Attorney General must report annually to Congress on activities related to informing individuals of their right to vote after federal felony convictions. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "chief election official," "election," "Federal office," and "State." SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. This section clarifies that the Act does not affect eligibility to vote in non-Federal elections and does not supersede the Voting Rights Act or the National Voter Registration Act.
